description: From hill +‎ billy (“fellow”). Compare Scots chapman billie (“travelling salesman”).

entries.meaning: (often derogatory) Someone who is from the hills; especially from a rural area, with a connotation of a lack of refinement or sophistication.
A white person from the rural southern part of the United States, especially the Southeastern states.

verbs.description: hillbilly (third-person singular simple present hillbillies, present participle hillbillying, simple past and past participle hillbillied)

entries.meaning: To emphasize one's rural or humble upbringing; to use unsophisticated charm.
To portray or act as an uneducated and unsophisticated fool.
To perform or experience stereotypically hillbilly-like actions.
